CENTERED	0001	473	82	1737	114	CONTRIBUTIONS FROM THE MUSEUM OF PALEONTOLOGY
CENTERED	0001	684	141	1523	177	THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
CENTERED	0001	791	1211	1422	1243	MUSEUM OF PALEONTOLOGY
CENTERED	0001	753	1263	1456	1295	THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
CENTERED	0001	973	1316	1238	1347	ANN ARBOR
CENTERED	0001	902	1720	1410	1752	<i>Editor: </i>RoaEzx V. KEsz,rvo
CENTERED	0002	333	1793	1811	1827	ABSTRACT â€” Eight new species of Plesiadapidae are described, bringing to eighteen 
CENTERED	0002	333	1838	1809	1871	the total number of valid North American species. A new genus, <i>Nannodectes, </i>is 
CENTERED	0002	332	1882	1809	1917	proposed for a lineage of four relatively small species with very narrow cheek teeth. 
CENTERED	0002	334	1927	1809	1962	The remaining species belong to the genera <i>Pxonothodectes </i>(2 sp.), <i>Plesiadapis </i>(8 
CENTERED	0002	333	1972	1809	2007	sp.), and <i>Chiromyoides </i>(4 sp.). Plesitarsiiformes and Simiolemuriformes are pro-
CENTERED	0002	332	2016	1812	2051	posed as suborders of Primates, replacing Plesitarsioidea and Anthrolemuroidea 
CENTERED	0002	374	2104	1812	2141	Thestratigraphic and phylogenetic relationshipsof the species of North American 
CENTERED	0002	335	2149	1811	2184	Plesiadapidae are outlined, and the Middle and Late Paleocene are divided into seven 
CENTERED	0002	333	2193	1810	2229	superposedbiostratigraphic zones based on the evolution of <i>P~onothodectes </i>and <i>Ple-</i>
CENTERED	0002	331	2238	1810	2274	<i>siadaPis. </i>The result is a detailed stratigraphic framework for the study of evolu-
CENTERED	0002	332	2283	1812	2319	tionary change in Paleocene mammals. The Clarkforkian mammal age is discussed 
CENTERED	0002	332	2328	1810	2364	briefly â€” on the basis of its correlation with European faunas, the Clarkforkian ap-
CENTERED	0002	941	2483	1230	2510	INTRODUCTION 
FOLLOWED	0002	270	2574	1942	2614	Species of <i>Plesiadapis </i>and its allies are among the most common mammalian fossils 
CENTERED	0002	222	2622	1943	2662	found in the Middle and Upper Paleocene continental deposits of North America and 
CENTERED	0002	223	2669	1940	2709	Europe. Estimates of the relative ages of Paleocene mammalian faunas have in the 
CENTERED	0002	223	2715	1941	2756	past often been based implicitly on the stage of evolution of the <i>Plesiadapis </i>they con-
CENTERED	0002	222	2762	1941	2804	tained, though the evolution of this genus was never studied in detail. Large samples 
CENTERED	0002	223	2809	1940	2850	of <i>Pxonothodectes </i>and <i>Plesiadapis </i>are nowknownfromnumerous localities widely dis-
CENTERED	0002	221	2856	1942	2897	tributed geographically and stratigraphically in North America. Thus it appeared that 
CENTERED	0002	222	2903	1940	2944	a careful study of the Plesiadapidae might yield results of general importance to the 
CENTERED	0002	224	3043	1942	3086	completed (Gingerich, 1974a), and a systematic revision of the family will eventually 
CENTERED	0002	221	3090	1940	3133	be published. In the meantime it seems advisable to make both the new taxa and the 
CENTERED	0002	223	3137	1942	3180	major stratigraphic conclusions available in this preliminary publication. One new 
CENTERED	0002	222	3184	1939	3227	genus and eight new species of Plesiadapidae are described here, followed by an outline 
CENTERED	0002	221	3231	1944	3274	of the phylogenetic relationships of the North American species and a discussion of a 
CENTERED	0002	222	3278	1941	3319	new biostratigraphic zonation of the Middle and Late Paleocene. Complete descriptions 
CENTERED	0002	220	3323	1938	3367	of the taxa, detailed stratigraphic documentation, adiscussionof plesiadapid evolution, 
CENTERED	0002	220	3371	1940	3412	and a discussion of the systematic position of the Plesiadapidae are included in the 
CENTERED	0002	221	3511	1942	3553	gave much valuable assistance with the photography. I also wish to thank the following 
CENTERED	0002	217	3557	1941	3600	for the loan of specimens described here: G. L. Jepsen, V. J. Maglio, and D. Baird of 
CENTERED	0002	220	3605	1939	3647	Princeton University (PU); R. J. <i>Emry </i>of the National Museum of Natural History, 
CENTERED	0002	217	3652	1942	3694	Washington (USNM); M. C. McKenna of the American Museum of Natural History, New 
CENTERED	0002	1051	3708	1108	3734	135
CENTERED	0003	860	634	1426	663	SYSTEMATIC PALEONTOLOGY 
FOLLOWED	0003	292	1006	1991	1050	<i>nothodectes, Nannodectes, </i>and <i>Plesiadapis, </i>since that tooth is generally the least vari-
FOLLOWED	0003	292	1152	1991	1190	<i>rare, </i>and the incisors are the most diagnostic element of its dentition. Table 2 gives 
CENTERED	0003	969	1318	1320	1348	<i>Order </i>PRIMATES

FOLLOWED	0003	287	2263	1991	2303	<i>nomen oblitum </i>Platychoeropidae Lydekker, 1887, and a proposalthat Platychoeropidae

CENTERED	0003	1546	2704	1667	2727	2. 1. 3. 3 
CENTERED	0003	1547	2750	1668	2774	2. 1. 3. 3
CENTERED	0004	829	2396	1342	2434	<i>Pronothodectes jepi </i>n. sp.
CENTERED	0004	945	2444	1238	2478	Pl. 1, figs. 1, 3
FOLLOWED	0004	274	2534	1937	2582	<i>Type. â€” </i>PU 14782, a left mandible with alveoli for Il 2 C P2, and the crowns of P3 4 
FOLLOWED	0004	278	2638	1942	2678	<i>Type locality. â€” </i>The type and 19 additional specimens were collected at the Rock 
FOLLOWED	0004	272	2733	1939	2772	<i>Diagnosis. â€” Pronothodectes j epi </i>is a significantly larger species than Pro. <i>matthetoi </i>
FOLLOWED	0004	268	2825	1938	2867	<i>Etymology. â€” </i>Named for the late Prof. G. L. Jepsen ("Jep', as he preferred to be 
CENTERED	0004	227	2873	1941	2915	called by students and friends) of Princeton University, in recognition of his important 
CENTERED	0004	228	2921	1939	2962	contributions to the study of Paleocene mammals. (Note: <i>Pronothodectes j epi </i>is not to 
CENTERED	0004	222	2968	1938	3010	be confused with <i>plesiadapis </i>jepseniGazin, a junior synonym of <i>ples. anceps </i>Simpson.)
CENTERED	0004	889	3085	1279	3122	<i>Nannodectes </i>n. gen.
FOLLOWED	0004	269	3179	1012	3219	<i>GenotyPe. â€” Nannodectes gasini </i>n. sp. 
FOLLOWED	0004	268	3224	1936	3266	<i>Included species. â€” </i>Genotype, <i>N. intermedius </i>(Gazin), <i>N. simpsoni </i>(Gazin), and <i>N. </i>
FOLLOWED	0004	219	3271	575	3312	<i>gidleyi </i>(Matthew). 
FOLLOWED	0004	266	3319	1937	3358	<i>Diagnosis. â€” </i>Species of <i>Nannodectes </i>differ from those of <i>Pronothodectes </i>in consis-
CENTERED	0004	222	3367	1938	3408	tently lacking I2. They differ from contemporaneous species of <i>Plesiadapis </i>in being 
CENTERED	0004	223	3414	1938	3455	smaller, retaining P2 and in most species the lower canine, having much narrower 
CENTERED	0004	223	3459	1937	3501	central incisors and cheek teeth (especially noticeable inthe lower premolars), having 
CENTERED	0004	221	3503	1935	3548	a more triangular P3 whichusually lacks aparaconule, and lacking a centroconule on I, 
CENTERED	0004	265	3553	1936	3595	<i>Etymology. â€” Nannos </i>(Gr.) dwarf, and <i>dektes </i>(Gr., masc.) biter, in reference to the 
CENTERED	0004	221	3602	1935	3641	relatively small size of species of this lineage compared to contemporaneous species 
FOLLOWED	0004	221	3649	514	3688	of <i>PlesiadaPis.</i>
CENTERED	0005	828	45	1328	84	<i>Nannodectes gazini </i>n. sp.
CENTERED	0005	940	93	1241	129	Pl. 1, figs. 2, 4

CENTERED	0015	1331	2682	1659	2712	MAJOR LOCAL I TIES
CENTERED	0015	222	1599	1941	1638	representing the species could not be unequivocally assignedto the Paleocene or to the 
CENTERED	0015	220	1645	1940	1685	Eocene. However, which epoch the fossils are assigned to is not really relevant to the 
CENTERED	0015	219	1691	1944	1733	question of faunal distinctness. The present study has shown that specimens of <i>Plesi-</i>
CENTERED	0015	223	1739	1940	1781	<i>adapis </i>cookei are limited to a definite biostratigraphic zone intermediate between the 
CENTERED	0015	222	1786	1943	1826	Tiffanian and Graybullian, lending considerable support to recognition of a distinct Clark 
CENTERED	0015	262	1879	1940	1919	<i>PlesiadaPis cookei </i>and the Clarkforkian have longbeenconsidered to be Late Paleo-
CENTERED	0015	220	1924	1941	1966	cene in age. Two facts argue against that age assessment: a) the earliest Perisso-
CENTERED	0015	219	1973	1942	2014	dactyla <i>(Hyyacotheritsm) </i>and Rodentia, forms marking the beginning of the Eocene in 
CENTERED	0015	217	2018	1941	2060	Europe, are present <i>in </i>the <i>Ples. </i>Cookei zone; b) Plesiadapis cooizei itself resembles 
CENTERED	0015	219	2067	1943	2108	closely a new species of <i>Plesiadapis </i>from the earliest Sparnacian fauna of Meudon in 
CENTERED	0015	216	2114	1940	2154	the Paris Basin (whereas the NorthAmericanPles. simonsiclosely resembles species 
CENTERED	0015	215	2161	1943	2201	from the European Cernay fauna). This suggests that the North American Clarkforkian 
CENTERED	0015	217	2207	1943	2249	should properly be considered Early Eocene inage(with the base of the Eocene defined 
CENTERED	0015	217	2254	1942	2295	as the base of the Paris Basin Sparnacian; see Gingerich, 1975, for discussion and 
CENTERED	0015	216	2301	1943	2341	references). Much of the confusion regarding both the Clark Fork fauna and the Sand 
CENTERED	0015	217	2347	1940	2390	Coulee fauna maybe due to their synonymy --both are now known to contain <i>Plesiadapis </i>
CENTERED	0015	218	2395	1941	2437	<i>cookei. </i>The upper beds of the <i>ples. coojzei </i>zone yield <i>pelycodus ralstoni, </i>a primate 
CENTERED	0015	217	2442	1941	2483	species characteristic of the Sand Coulee fauna, whereas a new larger species inter-
CENTERED	0015	215	2487	1941	2529	mediate morphologically between <i>p. </i>ralstoni and <i>P. tngonodms </i>is found in the lower 
FOLLOWED	0015	215	2536	1188	2577	<i>Gray </i>Bull beds (Gingerich and Simons, in prep.).

CENTERED	0016	882	3106	1261	3133	LITERATURE CITED
CENTERED	0016	261	2476	1930	2515	Lists of the major plesiadapid-bearing localities in North America are presented in 
CENTERED	0016	212	2523	1927	2561	text-fig. 2, with correlative localities listed alphabetically within each division. The 
CENTERED	0016	213	2569	1927	2608	relative stratigraphic position of each locality was determined by identifying the spe-
CENTERED	0016	213	2616	1929	2655	cies of Plesiadapidae from that locality, and then referring the locality to the proper 
CENTERED	0016	259	2710	1930	2748	Finally, it shouldbe noted that while the zonation illustrated in text-fig. 2 was derived 
CENTERED	0016	209	2756	1926	2795	from a study of Plesiadapidae, the stratigraphic positionof the localities listed will be 
CENTERED	0016	208	2804	1927	2843	the same for any other taxonomic group of vertebrates, and this sytem of zones thus 
CENTERED	0016	209	2852	1925	2890	provides a stratigraphic framework for studying the evolution of other groups as well. 
CENTERED	0016	211	2899	1928	2938	As additional evolutionary lineages of Paleocene mammals are studied in detail, it 
CENTERED	0016	211	2945	1926	2984	should be possible to increase further the resolution of the zonation through the pre-
